questions.question_text:
Examine the output of the asmcmd and srvctl commands:

//IMG//


You execute this command:

$ srvctl modify asm -count 2

All databases on the cluster are running from Oracle 12c homes.

Which statement is true about the outcome of this command?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C: reduced by one True
Effect: Oracle Clusterware will attempt to gracefully reduce the number of running ASM instances to match the new count (2 in this case). It will shut down one of the running ASM instances, likely the least loaded one, to reach the desired count. Since all database are running from 19c homes, all database instances will be using MGMTLSNR. This means they can still connect to the remaining ASM instances after one instance is shut down.

Selected Answer: A
Command doesn't shut down connected dbms instance

choices.D: The command fails because one ASM instance must be shut down manually before executing the command.
choices.B: The command fails because the instance count cannot be reduced to less than the minimum value of 3.
choices.A: ASM instances continue running on all three nodes until all database instances connected to one of the ASM instances shut down.
choices.C: One ASM instance is shut down and the instance count is reduced by one.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACF
No Clusterware files or Grid bin can be stored in ACFS

questions.question_text: Which three file types can be stored in an ASM Cluster file system (ACFS) and used by the relevant software? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Use the ls command in the asmcmd utility to view the location of voting files if stored in ASM.
choices.F: Use cat /etc/oracle/ocr.loc to view the location of the OCR if stored in ASM.
choices.A: Use cat /etc/oracle/olr.loc to view the location of the OCR and OLR if stored on a file system.
choices.E: Use crsctl query css votedisk to view the location of voting files if stored in a file system.
choices.D: Use the ocrcheck command to view the location of the OCR only if stored in a file system.
choices.C: Use crsctl query css votedisk to view the location of voting files if stored in ASM.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about displaying the location of voting files, OCR Files, or OLR files in Oracle Clusterware 19c on a UNIX system? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CEF
C and E are complementary

choices.B: Any database instance with the COMPATIBLE parameter 10.1 and later can use it.
choices.A: Files created using a template with the REDUNDANCY attribute set to HIGH will have three-way mirroring.
choices.C: The RECO diskgroup may only be used for the FRA.
choices.F: Files created using a template with the redundancy attribute set to MIRROR will have three-way mirroring.
choices.D: Files created in it have three copies for each allocation unit.
choices.E: The COMPATIBLE attribute values of the disk group can be changed to lower values.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
C is right, diskgroup may be used for FRA and not for general purpose as Oracle recommended here "Do not use the content.type attribute to distinguish the availability characteristics of disk groups that are used for a different purpose, such as those created to support a particular service.": https://docs.oracle.com/en/engineered-systems/exadata-database-machine/sagug/setting-oracle-asm-content-type.html

choices.B: Single Client Access Name (SCAN) virtual IP addresses (VIPs)
choices.D: Highly Available IP (HAIP) addresses used for the cluster interconnect
choices.C: Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) IP addresses

questions.question_text: Which two types of IP addresses does Oracle Clusterware 19c acquire from DHCP when it is started up on a cluster node using Grid Naming Service (GNS)? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Based on the sources, when Oracle Clusterware 19c starts up on a cluster node using Grid Naming Service (GNS), it acquires the following two types of IP addresses from DHCP:
•
Single Client Access Name (SCAN) virtual IP addresses (VIPs). When using GNS and DHCP, Oracle Clusterware configures the VIP addresses for the SCAN name. The SCAN VIPs are obtained from the DHCP server. The SCAN addresses resolve to the cluster, rather than to a node address in the cluster, which allows nodes to be added to or removed from the cluster without affecting the SCAN address configuration.
•
Node VIPs. When using GNS, each node in the cluster is assigned a virtual IP (VIP) address, which is obtained from the DHCP server. These node VIPs provide a stable address for clients to connect to the database, and can failover to another node if a node fails.
As a result, B & E are ture.

comments.content:
Updated. In summary, when using GNS, Oracle Clusterware obtains SCAN VIPs and node VIPs through DHCP.
1. SCAN vip
2. Node vip including Node vip & Node private ip
So the answer i pickup will be B, D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
IP for cluster interconnect are optionally in DHCP as oracle said here: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/cwwin/grid-naming-service-for-a-traditional-cluster-configuration-example.html
